PROPOSITION.TITRE: Instrumental and vocal music rarely mix in the Toraja language.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Each has its place, usages, and functions, which are separate in space and time. Now only residual, the different types of instrumental music are played solely for localized prophylactic or curative rituals. However, vocal music is sung at most of the great family or village rituals that punctuate Toraja life.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Almost all the instruments have disappeared today.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Musical instruments do not generally play a part in the daily life of the Toraja. Of the twenty-four instruments listed below, only eight are still played –most often to mark rituals only. The table lists those instruments once in use.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Table of instruments, grouped by family. The idiophones and membranophones predominate; no stringed instruments are commonly used in the present day; in the wind family, only the flute (suling) and horns (pompang) are still played.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Classification of instruments by rituals.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The Toraja classify their musical instruments solely according to the rituals in which they appear. After the name of the instrument, they add deata (‘divinity’) to indicate whether the instrument is used in the rituals of the East or of the West. In the East, they speak of suling deata (‘flutes of the divinities’) or gandang deata (‘drums of the divinities’).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Table of instruments, classified by ritual. Drums, flutes and fiddles were used in rituals, from both the West and the East, in different repertoires.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The officiants are designated through the names of musical instruments.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The symbolic charge given to a musical instrument does not correspond to its actual musical use. Most of the instruments are absent from both ritual and daily life, except for the drum and gong which themselves are never or hardly ever used musically.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: From Gelong Maro, recited at the maro ritual by the officiants, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The gandang drum is a ceremonial instrument.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The double-headed drum (gandang) with two buffalo-skin membranes, is cylindrical, with nailed heads; it is made from wood, either uru (Michelia celebica) or karurung ‘inside the palm’(Borassus). It is associated with the palm wine harvest: the trunk of the induk tree (Arenga Pinnata) must be tapped to obtain palm wine (tuak, ballo’). The drum is thus also made from old wine trees. It is kept hanging in the rice granary or house and is used only in rituals. When it is played it is placed on the ground, and its movement indicates occasions for sacrifices. It is not tuned.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The gandang drum is played in different ways.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: During playing, the drums may be suspended or may (at Mamasa) rest on the ground. Of various sizes, they can be grouped in three configurations –in ones, twos, or fours, and can be struck by one, two, or four players, who beat in interlocking patterns with a drumstick, or by hand. The drums are organized in pairs: a ‘woman’and ‘a man’. One pair is reserved for the rituals of the West and the other for those of the East.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The drum is used as a signalling instrument in the rituals of the West.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the funeral ritual, the drum announces the symbolic death of the deceased. If there is no drum, a rectangular rice mortar (issong) –pounded, beaten in cadence by several women –will be used as a drum to welcome the guests. It is then said, ‘it resounds like a drum’(digandangi). In the north three rhythmic motifs are played at the beginning of the celebration.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The first rhythm informs all within a wide range that a being of great nobility will be celebrated with the grandest pomp. Played continuously, the rhythm is known as digento tedong ‘lame buffalo’. Symbolically, this rhythm signifies that the deceased is ‘ill’but still not dead, though in fact dead long since. At the beginning of the first funeral it is played twice.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The drum rhythm gento tedong.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Then another beat announces the deceased’s death (dipamate). This beat is the signal of his ‘ritual’death –although the deceased has been dead for some time. This signifies that the physical body is really dead, though the deceased’s spirit is still present. Just after these strokes, the body, which had been lying in the southernmost room in west-east position, is removed to the central room and put in a north-south position. This change marks the start of the deceased’s spirit’s journey southwards. In this case the sound marks a putative, rather than actually, lived state.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The rhythm indicating the deceased’s symbolic death.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The rhythm, called (onomatopoeically) tenteng pumpung, is used at each ritual for the deceased (pangalukan to mate): for example when food is brought to the deceased or when the body is taken down to the sacrificial field.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The officiant (to minaa) Ne' Mendolo officiates alone in front of the drum, turned northwards. On the drum rest a ceremonial cloth, four pesung (offerings to the divinities, placed on banana leaves) as well as a saber (la'bo'). ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: At the maro ritual, the drum has both a ritual and a musical role: covered with a mixture of animal blood (mangrara gandang), it is ‘blooded with three bloods’(ditallung rarai) from different animals. Several drums are used, one for each house to be consecrated. One drum from every house taking part is taken down to the ceremonial field on the sixth day of celebration; beaten by several players, it makes the gellu’ dancers dance. For each drum there is a corresponding group of dancers and a ceremonial mastconsecrated by a song gelong bate performed by different groups of officiants for each mast.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The celebration opens with the drums entering the house (‘bringing the drums inside’ma'patama gandang): the drums are transported from the rice granary to the house, where they are played by the officiants (to minaa): placed on the ground, they are beaten by four drummers with a lath. Before being struck the drum(s) are consecrated with the blood of animals: a chicken and a pig are killed and a part of the meat put on the drums, as offerings to the deata, after which the drums may be beaten for two days. They are used to invoke the gods, chase away the evil spirits and purify the atmosphere. In every case, the drum’s entry and exit from the house are occasions for sacrifices –the meat will be placed on the drum and then offered to the divinities. (From H. Nooy-Palm 1986: 25, 64, 66, 75.)

I listed seven types of rhythm gathered under the term ‘bua’ drum’(pa' gandang bua’): 1. pa' kotok londong (‘the cock’s crow’) 2. pa' manuk mangarran (‘the brooding hen’) 3. pa' lettotana (‘breaking ground’) 4. panglelleng kayu (‘felling a tree’) 5. pa' sarangallo (‘very hot day’), 6. pangindo' sibarru (‘direct in twos’) 7. pa' lambuk issong pandan (‘rice-mortars rhythm’).

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The drum garatung is a pellet drum.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: This small hand drum with striker-balls is tied with laces; it has two python skin membranes, hence the name tandilo ula' (‘serpent zither’). The diameter of its skin is 9 cm, the same as the width of the sound box. This drum is not struck with the palm: a twist of the wrist makes the small wooden beads strike the skins, producing in turn a brisk and dry rattling.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The presence of the pellet drum is indubitably due to external influence.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The presence of this instrument, originating without doubt from Hindu-Buddhist cultures, is yet another indicator of the probable influence of Tantrism, followed in the ancient kingdoms of Sumatra and Java. This drum was once used as a secular instrument by Chinese peddlers in Indonesia (Nooy-Palm 1979: 304). Its name is attested in Sulawesi and other islands in the archipelago.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Tibetan officiants playing on the great damaru wooden drum in 1991. Photo in M. Helffer 1994: 249.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The damaru used to exist in Bugis country (B.F. Matthes 1872). Gamaru is found in the Bugis language. Karatu is found in the languages of Central Sulawesi (Kaudern [who spells the word in Dutch orthography, karatoe] 1927:139-145). 1927: 139-145). The pellets are not evoked. The drawings do not show any feature in common with the Toraja garatung. The karatoe is also evoked by Kruijt in Bare'e sprekende Toradja vol. 2: 380.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: A bissu monk, on the left, at Pare-Pare, 1991. Nowadays, the bissu transvestite priests use the term ‘gamaru’to designate the production of a whistling sound with a finger on the rim of a ceramic bowl, considered to invite the divinities to descend to earth (maddewata), an action well known in Tibetan Tantrism (Hamonic 1987: 36).

In the north of Toraja country (Bare'e), karatu designates another drum. Figure D: Karatu of the Poso region, in Kaudern 1927, Musical Instruments in Celebes: 141. The drum C is also a karatu of Mabungka. The instrument is classified within the cup-shaped drums. This drum belonged to priestesses.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The instrument garatung is known in India under the name of damaru (Pelras 1996: 71). This drum is also known in Tibet by the name of damaru, where it has an hourglass shape. An attribute of the god Shiva, it is also an attribute of numerous sages and religious masters (Helffer 1994: 233-250).

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Bombongan (or padaling) designates bronze kettle gongs, having either a shallow (southern Toraja) or a deep (northern Toraja) rim, and various diameters. These gongs are imported from Java or Bali at a high cost. Two types of gongs exist: the great gong, suspended at funerals, and the small processional chime.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The bombongan is used as status symbol.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The gong is reserved for the most elaborate funerals. While in the north the gong may be struck if seven buffaloes are sacrificed, in the south of the country it is only struck in the case of at least twenty-four buffaloes. In the scale of values the gong is thus the highest attribute, reserved for the high nobility. The dead man is said to be ‘gonged’(dibombonganni tu tau). Each village possesses only one gong.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Struck in isolation, the gong (bombongan) is used as a signalling instrument.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Invariably suspended, it is struck without any particular rhythm throughout the ritual: 1) to signify that the celebration is of the highest degree 2) to announce the guests’arrival 3) to announce the entrance of the animals, the gifts of the guests to the family. During the first funeral celebration it is struck for the procession to the sacrificial field, then, later, a few days before the body is placed on the sacrificial field.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Gongs are sometimes used together.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Rarely, in the northwest of the country, a gong-chime (a set of five suspended gongs of different sizes), padaling, is used. The scale includes four tones (Eb F G# B). As in the Philippines or Vietnam, the playing technique is rhythmic and not melodic. Each player plays a short cell in counterpoint with another in a repetitive cycle without variation. The players are hired from the Baruppu' region, for a million rupees, to intensify the funeral’s grandeur.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The Toraja suling is a ring-flute.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Found in the region of Rantepao, the suling is a ring-flute (with a rattan ring called dullik ‘make to match with a little thing’), 65 cm long, extended with a lower bell-like tip of buffalo horn (kolok or kolong suling: ‘rear support’). The flute is pierced with five or six front holes depending on the regions. Its ambitus extends over about three octaves.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: During a great funeral celebration, one or two flute players accompany one or two singers in the procession leading the guests to the reception site, or the deceased from the house to the site of the celebration. The tunes for leading the deceased to his grave have not been played for a long time.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: The flute’s sound takes the deceased’s shade downstream.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The function of the flute was to guide the deceased’s spirit (bombo) out from the village at nightfall several days after the final entombment. His spirit was considered to be still lurking in the house. It was then guided and directed by the whole family, preceded by the ‘flutes of the dead man’s spirit’suling bombo.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: In the rituals of the East, the flute is played in quartets in the prophylactic pakorong ritual.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The pieces for flutes are played in groups of four, in polyphony, with drone and soloist. They are an offering to the divinity Puang Maruru' in the case of epidemics or skin diseases.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The Toraja proffer musical and animal offerings to the divinity Ruru' to avert her anger. The role of the music is to seduce her, appease the suffering of the sick children (ditalintingngi ‘animate them with small noises’) and occasionally cure them. Thus, in the region of Pa' Buaran, the repertoire is called passuling Puang ‘God’s flute’or suling Datu Maruru' ‘the flute of Her Majesty Maruru'’or Paningoan Datu ‘the playing of Her Majesty’.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: At Mamasa, in the past, there were two types of ring flutes, including double flutes.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the Mamasa region, two types of ring flutes existed: double and single flutes. Mamasa flutes are longer (80 cm) than at Rantepao. They are pierced with five holes instead of six. Both in the west and the east the flute ensembles –quartet, quintet –are played in a healing rite; drone playing has an important role.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The healing flute (suling bonde) tradition is residual. The musical set consists of five long suling ring-flutes with five front non-equidistant playing holes. These flutes have a low register. Four play in unison on a continuous drone while the soloist sweeps the harmonic spectrum with a special blowing technique. The aim of this music was to cure malaria: the flautists came every evening for a month to the invalid, who would start to dance.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The tulali, extinct today, was recorded in the 1970s.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The word for this flute is an Austronesian term: Kruyt gives both the Wana and Loinang instruments as tulali. A turali flute is found in Sabah on the island of Borneo, among the Dusun (nose flute, rather short, Matusky 2004), in the Gorontalo region of Sulawesi, and in the eastern Fiji islands (Tryon ed. 1994). There’s also a Philippine nose-flute called tongali, and a Toba Batak and Simalungun Batak have bamboo flutes called tulila.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The pelle’ is an aerophone made in a way almost unique in the world.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The aerophone pelle’ is made from a rice stalk split in several places. This stalk serves as the reed (a rare case of a multiple reed). It is introduced into a funnel-shaped sugar palm leaf resonator. The player modifies the pitch (by two or three whole tones) and the timbre by a movement of his hand on the bell. The instrument is also known as barrung, oni-oni, poni-poni, panoni, tamorron, lullio, or liuk-liuk.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The instrument, which is loud, is played for the arrival of the guests and their animal offerings at the celebration bua’kasalle ceremonial site. It amplifies the celebration’s intensity; it announces the end of the harvests.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The karombi (bamboo jew’s harp).
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The tongue of the bamboo jew’s harp is worked by jerking a cord fixed to the frame, a technique common to all Indonesia. The tongue is inside the bamboo frame (Dournon 1978, Les guimbardes du Musée de l’Homme). L: 110, E: 1,4.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The jew’s harp was used in a healing rite.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the Sesean region, the jew’s harp was played at purification rites for sick children. The jew’s harp (karombi) and the fiddle (geso'-geso’) were played at the purification rite (mendio' ‘getting washed’).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Jew’s harp played by Pelipus Randan.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Pilipus Randan, born in 1932, an inhabitant of Batutumonga (Sesean), is a jew’s harp player. He lived for two years in Makassar, then ten in Rantepao, as an agricultural employee. He became a Christian in the 1950s. In 1949 he stopped playing the jew’s harp. Since 1991, he has taken it up again through a program of folklorization launched by the Makale cultural office. Since then he has played in hotels.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Description of the mendio' rite by the jew’s harp player.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The participants went to the well, the nobles first, then the others. After being bathed, the children had to play with the fish in a pig’s trough. If the child played aggressively he could regain his health; if, on the contrary, he showed no aggression, he remained ill. On this occasion the jew’s harp was played to entertain His Majesty Maruru'. The music is then called: ‘praise for His Majesty’ karombian Datu or ‘Playing for His Majesty’Paningoan Datu. According to the myth, Liling Sugi', a being descended from heaven (to manurun), brought the jew’s harp down to the earth.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Description of the one-stringed fiddle geso’-geso’.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Its soundboard is made from half a coconut with stretched goat-skin, or very rarely, horse-skin. The sound box, made from the palm areng (*enau) is 40 cm long; the long neck finishes in an end curved back in the form of a bird’s neck, like the katik carved at the top of certain houses next to the buffalo head. The string is pig’s gut, and the bow is made of bamboo. These fiddles are sometimes decorated with wood carvings.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Santung and tandilo both designate zithers: tube zither or stick zither. No longer in existence today these instruments are only present in poems as metaphors of instruments in general, or of the voice.

In Toraja, tandilo ula' (‘serpent zither’: striker ball drum; tandilo datu (‘divinity zither’): instrument used during rites against smallpox; tandilo rante ‘ceremonial field zither’, gong.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In Central Sulawesi, santung or sosanru designate a stick zither. The Toraja santung designates either a tube zither, or a stick zither. A coconut-shell resonator is partially closed by being held against the player’s chest. Veen (1940) describes a plucked string instrument (als een tokkelinstrument, waarvan de snaar zuiver aangeslagen wordt bij het tokkelen). For the Mandar, the tube zither is sattung. The Iban (central Sarawak) play on a tube zither (satong). In Timor, the tube zither is called sasando.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The bamboo fork buzzer (dongga) has disappeared.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The bamboo fork buzzer, once used during the pakorong ritual in certain places only (Saluputti), to repel smallpox. It is a bamboo percussion instrument 60 cm long and 7 cm wide. With two or three dongga of different sizes, several pitches could be heard. The length of the tongue determined the pitch. The instrument was held in one hand and hit with the other.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: It is called dongga by the Toraja, while in Central Sulawesi it is given the name rere, and ore-ore nggae or gongallima (hand jew’s harp) by the Tolaki of East Sulawesi, and duridana on Nias island. In fact, the sound it makes resembles that of the jew’s harp. .

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The katapi is a plucked boat lute.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The katapi or sudekan is a so-called ‘boat’lute, plucked, in black wood, with two strings tuned in fourths. The sound box, 100 cm (3 ft 3 inches) by 140 cm (4 ft 7 inches), is pierced with three sound-holes at the back. The fingers rest on finger-posts 3 to 5 cm high. This system of finger-posts is not found in other boat lutes in Indonesia, apart from the Bugis-Makassar kacapi/kacaping, Sumba and the Philippines (the kudyapi).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Toraja plucked lute (katapi). Personal collection, given by a grand father from Baruppu' region.
Back of katapi, from Baruppu'.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Distribution of plucked boat lutes in South Sulawesi and Indonesia.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: According to Philip Yampolsky (Music of Indonesia 15: South Sulawesi Strings, 1997: 8), the lutes of South Sulawesi called kacapi (Bugis, Mandar), kacaping (Makassar) and katapi (Toraja) belong to a family of “boat lutes,”most of them with similar names, (e.g., hasapi, sampeq, sapi, konyahpi) found in many parts of western and central Indonesia –as far east as Sumba, but not in Java or Bali. Another member of the family is found in Thailand and Cambodia, where it is called chapei. Yet another, kudyapi, is found in the Philippines. Their curved form gave rise to the descriptive term of ‘boat lutes’.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Detail of the sound box of a large plucked lute from Mamasa, personal collection.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The plucked lute was certainly borrowed from the lowland Bugis.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The plucked lute kacapi of South Sulawesi is distinguished from all the other lutes of the archipelago (except Sumba) by its finger-posts (between four and six) carved on the neck and resembling little pillars measuring between 3 and 7 cm. In Toraja country, the lute katapi, probably an import, only exists residually. In addition, it is not known if it ever had its moment of glory. It is not mentioned in the musicologists’first descriptions (Cf. Kunst 1946/1994: 182-183), nor in the great Toraja ritual words, otherwise so rich in allusions to musical instruments.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Plucked lute (kacapi) on the left. Photo: C. Pelras.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Data on the Bugis plucked lute.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Its size is reduced: although the dimensions of the lutes vary from one group to the other, on average the instrument measures between 80 and 90 cm (about 2 ft 6 inches to 3 ft). Whereas its neck resembles an oar, the other side recalls the gables of Bugis or Toraja houses, which are also shaped like a boat or upturned saddle. In its original form the instrument’s neck and body were made from the same piece of wood. A resonant cavity is left open at the back, to be closed with a separate wooden board in which three holes have been pierced. In the south of Sulawesi, all the plucked lutes have two strings.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the south of Sulawesi, the plucked lute is found in all communities –Bugis, Makassar and Mandar.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Katapi playing in Toraja country.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The plucked lute is uncommon among the Toraja. The only time I heard a plucked lute was during the ma’pakorong ritual, in which a lute duo performed. From the Bugis (neighboring people in the plains):, the Toraja have borrowed some kacapi duo that accompanies songs in Bugis language. The music of this duo is typically Bugis in rhythm, in its use of alternating singers, and in its nasal timbre.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The plucked lute (katapi) in the region of Mamasa (West Toraja).
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Although no plucked lute playing tradition can be found in the east of the Toraja country, a tradition of lute accompanied singing exists, however, among the western Toraja, known as ma' anduru in the Mamasa region. The instrument appears to come from the province of Mambi, in the west of Mamasa, and in some parts of the Mandar coast. It may have replaced the tandilo. The two strings are tuned in fourths.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Large boat lute from Mamasa, personal collection.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The Mamasa lute, made from black wood and boat-shaped, is distinguished from the lutes of the plains by its large size, and the length of its neck, recalling the lutes of Borneo or the Philippines. The example measures 1.38 m. (4 ft 6 inches). The neck alone measures 39 cm. (1 ft 3 inches). It has two strings. The sound box is pierced with three holes at the back. The katapi’s sonority is clear and powerful. Its construction clearly resembles that of the Bugis lute kacapi as it has four or five finger-posts and a bridge. However, in use the player only uses three finger-posts.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The plucked lute accompanies the male solo song called anduru'. The song accompanied by the lute recounts historic episodes, praises the master of the house (ditendeng), and the audience, and then acts as intermediary between man and woman.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The flute-and-horn bands were formed with the arrival of the missionaries.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Among the Toraja, the popularity of bands called musik bambu, combining monophonic (one-pitch) horns and transverse flutes,is such that nowadays musik bambu is staged as traditional Toraja music. Various instruments make up these bands.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Flute-and-horn band, Mamasa, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The six-holed transverse flute was first introduced in Sulawesi by the heads of Moluccan missionary schools in the first part of the nineteenth century. The Ambonese, long Protestant, were frequently employed in public administration, as they were often trilingual (in Ambonese, Malay and Dutch). Christian schoolteachers from Ambon and Minahasa were sent into the Toraja country to fulfill educational functions from 1910 up till the middle of the twentieth century. They also taught in the schools and made no secret of their desire to convert their pupils: they had a dual role –to teach and evangelize. In the schools they taught the children to make and play transverse flutes. That is why the Toraja still speak of ‘compulsory flute’(*suling wajib). Everywhere in Central Sulawesi and Toraja country the bamboo transverse flute was used in primary school music classes. Every school had –and still has –its flute band. Children walking to school over long distances would practise their instrument on the way (Bigalke 1981; Kaudern 1927; Harahap 1952: 15).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Transverse flutes, Toraja country, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The bamboo horns (pompang) are attested from 1930 in a photo taken by Jaap Kunst showing children playing horns at Makale. According to some Toraja, the horns were introduced by the Manadonese around 1942. These flute-and-horn bands socialized young people in such way that conversions to Christianity were promoted. Pompang music may probably come from the musik melulu (bamboo horns called musik bas) of Sangir-Talaud, a group of Indonesian islands located just south of the Philippines. These bands also exist in Malaysia, in the state of Sabah, and in the southern Philippines (Taylor 1989: 15).

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The flute-and-horns (pompang) are played in bands by school children.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: A band of ‘pompang music’is made up of young school children playing transverse bamboo flutes (suling bambu melintang) who play the melody, and horns (pompang) of different sizes, rectangular in form, which ensure the harmony. Sometimes, a drum may accompany the band. The scale is diatonic. The recently introduced transverse flute is used only in these formations.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: As each horn is able to produce only one pitch, a band needs 15 horns. According to Pa’Patadungan, a pompang formation covers a range of three octaves.

PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Created in schools, these pompang bands have been taking part in funeral celebrations since the 1950s. Today, competitions between regions are held at governmental celebrations.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Today, these pompang bands have become a sign of identity, a real Toraja ethnic marker. They bear witness to a form of controlled socialization characteristic of several regions of Indonesia, and are one of the main attractions offered to tourists in or outside the large hotels.
